awd_titl_txt: Petrogenetic Studies of Young Volcanic Rocks
awd_abstract_narration: This is an Accomplishment Based Renewal by an outstanding scientist who is a member of the US National Academy of Sciences and universally acknowledged by members of the marine geology community as one of the leaders in the field.  His research, over the past few decades, has transformed our understanding of magmatic process occurring at mid-ocean ridges and convergent margins like Cascadia and the Aleutians in the US and Japan in Pacific. In both volcanic environments, melts arising from the mantle come to the surface and produce the volcanoes and lavas that form the floor of the oceans and island arc volcanic chains.  This renewal builds off the investigator's work over the last five years in improving our understanding of seafloor volcanism, including the creation of an internally consistent geochemical and geophysical database for which over 1,000 new high quality major and trace element analyses of seafloor volcanic rocks were collected and then combined with thousands of other similar data collected from the scientific literature.  This has provided the essential data needed to test global models of mantle temperature and composition.  The new research will allow determination of the relationship between basalt composition and the physical properties and variables of mid-ocean ridges on a global scale; determine the principles that control the extent of mantle melting, compositional fractionation, and magma mixing; identify magma sources and source heterogeneity; and determine the causes of the disconnect between mantle temperatures and lava trace element geochemistry.  This work will also involve the creation of a similarly comprehensive geochemical database for ocean island basalts, which can be used with geophysical information such as island size, volume, height above the seafloor, and tectonic plate age and thickness to illuminate the origin and evolution of ocean islands and identify commonalities and global trends.  Broader impacts of the work include support of an early career collaborating scientist whose gender is under-represented in the sciences, training of a graduate students, and building infrastructure for science in terms of creating a new comprehensive community dataset that will be publicly accessible and can be used to test and constrain models for the formation and growth of ocean islands over time.

por.por_cntn:
More than two thirds of Earth's volcanism occurs hidden from view at ocean ridges, where two thirds of Earth's crust has been created. Ocean ridges are a 50,000 km (30,000 mile) long string of volcanoes, where eruptions are occurring frequently. The challenge to studying them is that they are almost entirely hidden from view at the bottom of the ocean, and difficult and expensive to access. Because the samples that have been recovered are relatively rare and precious, we need to maximize the information we can obtain from them. From research cruises spanning more than three decades, our laboratory has collected thousands of valuable samples. The aim of this proposal was to maximize the scientific utility of these samples by collecting new and better data, and using that data to make new discoveries, to test and constrain existing hypotheses about Earth's volcanism, and to learn more about Earth's interior from which the volcanic rocks are derived.

     To this end we developed new methods of chemical analysis that are able to produce better data more than ten times faster than existing methods. With the benefit of this development, instead of being limited by time and resources to analyzing a few samples, we are able to obtain much more complete data sets.  When more data are available, then signals that were in the noise can emerge, and new discoveries can be made.

   The general framework of Earth's volcanism is the "plate tectonic geochemical cycle". (Figure 1). New ocean crust is created at ridges, and then it spreads away from the ridge and ultimately is recycled to Earth's interior at convergent margins. Where the plates are recycled, a long line of beautiful stratovolcanoes (like Mt Fuji in Japan) are created. As it goes deeper and mixes back into the mantle, the recycled crust then also creates heterogeneities that can be sampled by later volcanism, though the exact mechanism by which that happens is vigorously debated. There are also "hot spots" like Hawaii that can form separately from plate boundaries.  Our aim is to understand how all of these are related to one another.

     As often happens in science, the new data turned up unanticipated discoveries. We discovered a previously unknown, distinct chemical province between Australia and Antarctica.  By examining the new and expanded global data set, we also discovered that there is a east-west hemispheric division in the composition of the ocean crust, which relates to the blanket of plates being returned to the mantle around the Pacific. These plates block communication between the Pacific and Atlantic , which we interpreted as a "subduction shield" (Figure 2).

  Our new ocean ridge data also enabled us to reinterpret the data from the stratovolcanoes at convergent margins. These had mostly been interpreted to come from a homogeneous mantle source, but we showed instead that the mantle at convergent margins has the same range of variability as at ocean ridges-- which actually makes a lot of sense. This led us to a new synthesis of convergent margin data that enabled a quantitative model that applies globally. We were also able to show definitively that convergent margin mantle sources are more oxidized than ocean ridge sources.

     The controversy over the fate of recycled plates is whether they are incorporated as homogeneous solids into the convecting mantle, or whether they are reprocessed by melting in Earth?s deep interior. By examining data for the volatile molecules CO2 and H2O, we were able to show that melting of crust is very important and explains many aspects of the volcanism of ocean island basalts.

     Therefore by getting better data and interpreting it carefully, we were able to identify new domains of Earth's crust, and develop and constrain models that account for both volcanism at the surface and the composition of Earth's interior.

     This work contributed to the scientific development of undergraduates, graduate students, post-docs and junior scientists. It established useful collaborations with scientists and students in Korea and China, contributing to the international effort that scientific progress entails. The methods we have developed will be broadly useful to laboratories around the world, the new data sets will be widely used for diverse problems, and our work has implications for other disciplines in Earth science such as tectonics, geophysics and the interpretation of seismological data.
